Screening of different solid acid catalysts for glycerol acetylation Maria Luisa Testa ⁎ Valeria La Parola Leonarda F. Liotta Anna Maria Venezia Istituto per lo Studio dei Materiali Nanostrutturati, UOS-PA CNR, via U. La Malfa 153, I-90146 Palermo, Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +39 0916809253; fax: +39 0916809399. Graphical abstract Highlights ► SO3H-SBA shows the best activity and selectivity for glycerol acetylation. ► SO3H-SBA exhibits high stability with no leaching of acidic groups during 5 cycles. ► The balance acid sites/surface density is a key factor for activity and selectivity. ► Despite high acidity, Amberlyst-15 shows low selectivity to triacetyl product. Different solid acid catalysts, sulfonic acid functionalized amorphous and mesoporous silicas, titania doped silica HMS, sulfated zirconia and niobic acid, were synthesized, characterized and tested in the esterification reaction of glycerol. Their catalytic performance was compared with that of commercial Amberlyst-15. Fresh and spent materials were analyzed by means of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, N2 adsorption isotherms and acid capacity measurements. Among all the catalysts the mesoporous sulfonic silica presented the best performance in term of reactivity, with the total conversion of glycerol in 30min of reaction, and in term of stability, with no leaching of sulfonic groups of catalyst. The catalytic activity of the materials was related to their acid capacities as well as to the strength and surface density of acidic sites. Keywords Glycerol Esterification Solid acid catalyst TAG 1 Introduction In recent years, due to the increasing price of fossil fuel and to the environmental concern there has been a considerable interest in developing biodiesel as alternative fuel. Biodiesel is a mixture of fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) produced by the transesterification of triglycerides with methanol. One of the major problems, during the production of biodiesel, is the formation of glycerol (10wt%) as principal by-product. Different chemical transformations of glycerol into high-value chemicals have been developed to produce propanediols, acrolein, hydroxyaceton, glyceric acid [1–4]. Among the different reactions, the esterification of glycerol into acetins (Scheme 1 ) is quite attractive due to the versatile industrial application of the final products, going from cosmetic to fuel additives [5]. In particular, mono- (MAG) and diacetin (DAG) could be used as solvent, plasticizer, softening agent and solvent for dyes. Triacetin (TAG), is the most useful acetin, being used as an antiknock additive for gasoline. Addition of small amounts of TAG into biodiesel improves the fuel cold and viscosity. Conventionally, esterification reactions are industrially performed under batch conditions in homogeneous liquid phase catalyzed by strong Brønsted acids, such as sulfuric acid, hydrochloric acid or ortophosphoric acid. Efforts are being made to turn the process into “green” chemical reaction working on solvent-free methodologies, heterogeneous catalysts, reagents ratio and catalyst loading. The use of a large number of heterogeneous solid acid catalysts, including resins (such as Amberlyst-15) or zeolites [6–8], niobic acid [6], zirconia [9] and heteropolyacids [10,11] for the glycerol esterification reaction has been reported in recent literature. Activated Amberlyst-15 acid resins [6] in comparison with niobic acid and zeolites presented the best performance, with the highest conversion (97%) of glycerol and selectivity to DAG (54%) and TAG (13%) products. Liao et al. [7] proposed, over resins or zeolites, a two-step method in which the esterification of glycerol was followed by acetylation with acetic anhydride. The use of acetic anhydride improved the reaction until yielding TAG as only product, but this procedure did not result so convenient due to the high amounts of waste and to the price of acetic anhydride, that is much more higher than acetic acid. Dosuna-Rodriguez and Gaigneaux [8] studied the catalytic performance of ion exchange resins in glycerol acetylation carried out in presence of a large excess of glycerol. The use of sulfonic functionalized SBA silica in the esterification of glycerol with acids is described by Perez-Pariente et al. [12] and Hermida et al. [13], who reported the glycerol acetylation with lauric acid, while Melero et al. [14] studied the reaction in the presence of acetic acid. In the above-mentioned works, different reaction conditions were used, in particular, ratio glycerol to acetic acid, reaction temperature and the kind of catalyst and loading were changed in order to obtain a maximum in glycerol conversion with maximum selectivity toward DAG and TAG. Some studies were carried out at high pressure [15] or with high molar ratio acetic acid:glycerol [16] or high catalyst loading [6]. Esterification of an alcohol is strongly dependent on the experimental condition used, therefore, it is not easy to make direct comparison between the different catalytic performance of materials reported in literature. Thus, the purpose of this work is to compare under the same experimental conditions the acetylation reaction of glycerol catalyzed by different solid acid catalysts in order to investigate the effect of their intrinsic properties on the activity. Niobic acid, titania doped silica HMS, sulfated zirconia and sulfonic acid functionalized amorphous and mesoporous silicas were synthesized and tested in the esterification reaction. The results were compared with blank, homogeneous and commercial Amberlyst-15 catalyzed reactions. The effects of glycerol:acetic acid ratio, reaction time, reaction temperature and catalysts loading were investigated. Fresh and spent materials were analyzed by means of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, N2 adsorption isotherms and acid capacity measurements. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of niobic acid (Nb2O5·nH2O) Niobic acid nanoparticles were prepared by dissolving niobium chloride (NbCl5, 5g) into 10ml of ethanol and adding to the resulting yellow solution 200ml of NH3 solution (0.3M) [17]. The obtained white precipitate of niobic acid was filtered, washed several times with water in order to remove residual chlorides and dried overnight at 120°C. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Ti10HMS The titanium containing mesostructured HMS with composition 10wt% of TiO2–90wt% SiO2 (labeled as Ti10HMS) was synthesized using tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) (Aldrich) and Ti(iso-OC3H7)4 (Aldrich) as silicon and titanium precursors, respectively, following the steps reported in a previous work [18]. Basically, HMS was assembled from 4:1 molar mixtures of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) (Aldrich) as the inorganic precursor and dodecylamine (DDA) (Aldrich) as the structure-directing surfactant in 90:10 (v/v) water/ethanol. About 49mmol of DDA were dissolved in 50ml of ethanol and 450ml of H2O. To the surfactant solution, heated to 60°C, 196mmol of TEOS plus 16.3mmol of Ti(iso-OC3H7)4 were added. The gel mixture was kept in a closed Teflon vessel at 60°C for 20h. The reaction product was filtered, washed with distilled water and dried at room temperature for 24h. The surfactant was removed by calcination in air at 500°C for 4h. 2.1.3 Synthesis of sulphated zirconia Sulphated zirconia sample was prepared by one-pot sol–gel synthesis using zirconium n-propoxide, Zr(OPr)4 (70wt% solution in 1-propanol) as precursor [19]. In a typical preparation, the proper amount of Zr(OPr)4 solution was mixed under stirring with 2-propanol, as solvent, then the calculated amount of sulphuric acid (96%, Aldrich) was added dropwise and, finally, a solution composed by H2O/2-propanal was introduced drop by drop. The H2O/Zr molar ratio was set equal to 60, the sulphuric acid/Zr molar ratio was 0.21 and the total 2-propanol/Zr ratio was wet equal to 14. After aging at room temperature for 30min a gel was obtained, which was dried step wise from 40 to 100°C in order to obtain the final xerogel (labeled as dry SZ). The temperature steps consisted of 17h at 40°C, 6h at 70°C, 17h at 90°C and 2h at 100°C. A portion of the dry-SZ was calcined at 470°C for 5h (SZ-470). 2.1.4 Synthesis of the propyl-SO3H functionalized amorphous SiO2 Propyl-SO3H functionalized silica was synthesized by sol–gel technique according to a published procedure [20]. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) (7.5ml, 0.034mol, Aldrich) was dissolved in ethanol (5ml) and stirred at 45°C for 15min. Then, 5ml of aqueous solution of acetic acid at pH 5 was added to the mixture, followed by 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxy silane (MPTMS) (0.625ml, 0.0034mol, Aldrich) and hydrogen peroxide (33%, w/v solid:liquid ratio of 1:18). The solution was heated up to 80°C and left at this temperature until the formation of the gel was achieved. The obtained wet gel (labeled as SAS) was dried at 120°C overnight. 2.1.5 Synthesis of the propyl-SO3H functionalized SBA-15 Propyl-SO3H functionalized SBA-15 was prepared according to the procedures described before [21,22]. Pluronic P123 (4.0g, Aldrich) was dissolved in a solution of 2M HCl (125ml). To this solution TEOS (8.2ml, 0.037mol), MPTMS (0.69ml, 0.0037mol) and hydrogen peroxide (33%, w/v solid:liquid ratio of 1:18) were added and stirred overnight at 40°C in a 250ml one neck flask. The milky suspension was aged at 100°C for 24h in a closed PP bottle and, then, a solid product was filtered and washed with ethanol. The surfactant was removed by ethanol washing under reflux for 24h. The final product (labeled as SSBA) was dried at 120°C overnight. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Acid capacity and concentration of sulfonic groups were determined by titration with 0.01M NaOH (aq) [23]. In a typical experiment, 0.1g of solid was added to 10ml of deionized water. The resulting suspension was allowed to equilibrate and thereafter was titrated by dropwise addition of 0.01M NaOH solution using phenolphthalein as pH indicator. The acidity of oxide catalysts was also determined by measurements of temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD). The sample amount of ∼0.1g was out-gassed in a 5vol.% O2/He flow at 120°C for 30min. Then, ammonia adsorption was performed by admitting a flow of 5% NH3/He stream (30ml/min) at room temperature for 1h. After purging with 100ml/min He flow for 1h at 100°C and then cooling down to room temperature, the catalyst was heated under He (30ml/min) in a linear rate of 10°C/min to 500°C and the ammonia desorption was monitored by online TCD and mass quadrupole spectrometer (Thermostar™, Balzers). Before gas detection, a cold trap was used to condense any water desorbed from the sample. In the range of temperature investigated, up to 500°C, no decomposition of propyl sulfonic group was observed for acid functionalized amorphous and mesoporous silicas. A good agreement between TCD signal and NH3 QM signals was found. For accuracy, the total acidity of the catalyst was calculated by integration of NH3 desorption profile referred to the QM signal at mass 15. The textural properties were obtained using a Carlo Erba Sorptomat 1900 instrument. The fully computerized analysis of the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77K allowed to obtain, through the BET method in the standard pressure range 0.05–0.3 p/p 0, the specific surface areas of the samples. The total pore volume, V p was evaluated on the basis of the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.998, while mesopore size distribution values and mesopore volumes were calculated by applying BJH model in the range of p/p 0 of 0.1–0.98 [24]. X-ray diffraction patterns were measured with a Bruker vertical goniometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation. A proportional counter and 0.05° step sizes in 2θ were used. The assignment of the various crystalline phases was based on the JPDS powder diffraction file cards [25]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyses were performed with a VGMicrotech ESCA 3000 Multilab, equipped with a dual Mg/Al anode. The spectra were excited by the unmonochromatized Al Kα source (1486.6eV) run at 14kV and 15mA. The analyzer operated in the constant analyzer energy (CAE) mode. For the individual peak energy regions, a pass energy of 20eV set across the hemispheres was used. Survey spectra were measured at 50eV pass energy. The sample powders were mounted on a double-sided adhesive tape. The pressure in the analysis chamber was of the order of 10−8 Torr during data collection. The constant charging of the samples was removed by referencing all the energies to the C 1s set at 285.1eV, arising from the adventitious carbon. The invariance of the peak shapes and widths at the beginning and at the end of the analyses ensured absence of differential charging. Analyses of the peaks were performed with the software provided by VG, based on non-linear least squares fitting program using a weighted sum of Lorentzian and Gaussian component curves after background subtraction [26,27]. Atomic concentrations were calculated from peak intensity using the sensitivity factors provided with the software. The binding energy values are quoted with a precision of ±0.15eV and the atomic percentage with a precision of ±10%. 2.3 Esterification reaction In a typical experiment, acetic acid (32.6mmol, Aldrich) was added to a mixture of glycerol (1g, 10.87mmol, Aldrich) and catalysts (50mg). Mass ratio of catalyst/glycerol corresponding to 5wt% and molar ratio acetic acid:glycerol corresponding to 3:1 were used. The reaction was carried out in a 25ml round bottom flask connected to water-cooled condenser. The reaction mixture was continuously stirred using a magnetic stirrer and refluxed at 105°C. The products were analyzed by GC–MS on a GCMS-QP5050A Shimadzu mass spectrometer with ionization energy of 70eV and their chromatograms were in accord with those obtained from reference samples. The final solution was then filtered to recover the catalyst that was dried at 120°C overnight and reused in further reactions. For comparison purposes, blank, homogeneous and commercial Amberlyst-15 (Aldrich) catalyzed reactions were performed by stirring glycerol (10.87mmol) and acetic acid (32.6mmol) at a temperature of 105°C, without catalyst or with 14.6mg p-toluensulfonic acid (p-TSA) or 50mg of Amberlyst-15, respectively. The amount of p-TSA was chosen to have the same amount of mmolH+ as the SSBA, the best catalyst of the series. The products were analyzed by GC–MS. 2.4 Catalyst reusability Recycling experiments were performed over the most active catalysts of the series, SAS, SSBA and Amberlyst-15. After the reaction, the catalysts were filtered, washed with methanol in order to clean the catalyst surface, dried, activated at 120°C overnight and reused. 3 Results and discussion In order to identify the crystalline phases of the synthesized samples X-ray diffraction analyses were performed. For SAS, SSBA and Ti10HMS, a broad peak at 2θ =22° attributable to the amorphous framework of silica was found. No TiO2 lines were visible in the XRD pattern of Ti10HMS. Amorphous profiles were also registered for Nb2O5·nH2O, dry-SZ and SZ-470. In Table 1 the values of surfaces areas, pores diameter, total pores volume and mesopore volume of all samples are reported. The silica-based samples (SAS, SSBA and Ti10HMS) were characterized by high surface areas, above 500m2 g−1 and high total pore volumes. As expected in SSBA and Ti10HMS, the greater part of the pore volume was due to mesopores, while in the SSA sample only a fourth of pores were in the mesopores range. Fig. 1 shows the adsorption–desorption isotherms relative to SSBA and SSA, in which the different pore structures is evidenced by the differences in the hysteresis. Moreover, in the inset, the pore diameter distribution of SSBA sample, centered at 9.4nm, is showed. All other samples had lower surface areas, ranging between 20 and 120m2 g−1 and lower pore volumes. Acidity properties of selected samples were evaluated by NH3-TPD. The technique provides information on the total acidity of the solids, without distinguishing between Brønsted and Lewis acidity but accounting for the different strength of acid sites. The TPD curves (as TCD signal) registered in the range of temperature between 50 and 500°C are shown in Fig. 2 where three temperature zones associated to the acid sites strength (weak, medium and strong) were detected according to the literature [9]. The results are summarized in Table 2 , in terms of mmolg−1 of desorbed NH3. The most striking feature of Fig. 2 is the high intensity of ammonia desorption peak for Amberlyst-15. Such peak centered at 360°C is indicative of strong acid sites, giving the main contribution. A small peak due to medium acid sites was observed at around 260°C. The NH3-TPD profile of SSBA was characterized by a main peak, centered at 270°C, indicative of the presence of medium Brønsted acid sites likely due to the sulfonic groups [13]. A small contribution, at around 160°C, due to weak acid sites is also detected. As compared with SSBA, the amorphous SSA exhibited a wider TPD profile characterized by two main peaks at 240 and 305°C, attributed to medium acid sites of slightly different strength. The shoulder at 180°C confirmed a contribution of weak acid sites. Dry-SZ gives rise to a wide NH3 desorption curve, less intense as compared to silica samples, with a maximum at 250°C. According to the literature, the pattern is due to weak and medium acid sites [9]. Ti10HMS and Nb2O5·nH2O desorbed significantly smaller amount of NH3 with respect to the above silicas and dry-SZ samples. Ti10HMS showed desorption in the low-temperature region, giving a peak centered at 150°C, indicative of both, weak and medium acids sites. Nb2O5·nH2O desorbed a very small amount of ammonia, between 200 and 300°C, due to medium sites, and a small amount of ammonia at higher temperature, 350–450°C due to the contribution of strong acid sites. Acid capacity of the samples was also determined by titration with 0.01M NaOH (aq). The results in terms of mmolH+ g−1 and surface density mmolH+ m−2 are reported in Table 2. The values obtained by the two techniques are comparable and confirmed Amberlyst-15 as the most acidic sample while Ti10HMS as the least. The difference between Amberlyst-15 and all the other samples is more evident in terms of density. Scheme 1 shows the acetylation reaction of glycerol and its conversion into monoacetylglycerols (MAG), diacetylglycerol (DAG) and triacetylglycerol (TAG). MAG and DAG include two different isomers depending on the acetylation position within the glycerol molecule. Acetylation reaction was studied in the presence of different solid acid catalysts and the catalytic behavior of the materials was evaluated in terms of conversion of glycerol and selectivity toward MAG, DAG and TAG. The reaction was carried out in the absence of solvent and at a temperature of 105°C with an acetic acid:glycerol molar ratio corresponding to 3:1. The reaction was monitored during 1–3h and thereafter the products were analyzed by GC–MS. The only products of the reaction were the corresponding acetins and, in contrast with literature [6,11,28], no other minority product due to dehydration process was found. The glycerol conversion and the selectivity to the three acetins as a function of the various catalysts are summarized in Table 3 and, for selected samples, depicted in Fig. 3 . When the reaction was carried out in the absence of catalyst the conversion of glycerol was 36% in 1h and 85% in 3h, the ester distribution was oriented toward the formation of MAG and only a 2% of TAG was detected after 3h. The use of niobic acid, Ti10HMS and sulfated zirconia both SZ-470 and dry-SZ produced slightly higher conversion of glycerol during the course of reaction. The catalytic behavior of Ti10HMS and SZ-470 was very similar with a conversion of glycerol of 90% and 91%, respectively, after 3h. A particular attention has been given to the dry sulfated zirconia that catalyzed an initial (1h) conversion of alcohol (63%) higher than the corresponding SZ-470 (47%) but lead to a higher yield in MAG. Niobic acid presented a glycerol conversion lower (51%) than the other studied catalysts and comparable to the blank reaction. Finally, when sulfonic acid functionalized amorphous (SAS) and mesoporous silicas (SSBA) were tested in the acetylation reaction, the full conversion of glycerol was obtained in only 1h with a selectivity, after 3h, to the desired TAG of 49% and 33%, respectively. As concern the selectivity, it is important to note that after only 1h MAG has almost disappeared, DAG was the major product that was turning into TAG. The rate of formation of DAG can be explained with a multiple nucleophilic attack of the hydroxyl group of glycerol. Notably, the formation of TAG occurred already during the first hour. For comparison purposes also p-TSA in homogenous phase and commercial Amberlyst-15, as heterogeneous catalyst, were used in the acetylation reaction. Amberlyst-15 showed similar conversion of glycerol to that of both p-TSA and sulfonic silicas but quite different distributions of esters, with a worst selectivity toward the di- and tri-acetylated products (see Fig. 3). Moreover, the distribution of the products did not change with reaction time and this could be due to the deactivation of the catalytic sites by water, produced as by-product of the reaction. The sulfonic groups of the Amberlyst-15 result, in fact, much stronger than the others, as seen by NH3-TPD (Fig. 2) causing the water to be irreversible absorbed [29]. All the described reactions were carried out using the same amount of catalyst (50mg), and therefore different total acidic capacity. As shown in Fig. 4 , the conversions correlate well with the acidic concentration. Sulfonic amorphous and mesoporous silicas with acid capacities of 2.10 and 1.54mmol/g, respectively, showed the best activity with a total conversion of glycerol in only 1h and a good selectivity to TAG. Interestingly, Amberlyst-15, in spite of a very high acid capacity (4.24mmol/g) and a good conversion of glycerol, showed a worse selectivity toward triacetin, in comparison with sulfonic silicas catalysts. The activity of Amberlyst-15 is difficult to be compared to that of sulfonic mesoporous silica catalysts because of almost total glycerol conversion over these samples. For this reason, efforts to lower the glycerol conversion were attempted, in order to better discriminate the performance of SSBA (as reference) and Amberlyst-15. The activity of the two catalysts, obtained by decreasing the catalyst amount (25mg) or the reaction temperature (60°C), led, in both cases, to the same glycerol conversion (see above in the text Table 4 ), indicating that the total amount of sulfonic groups was very high in such systems. The glycerol acetylation reaction was also carried out with dry-SZ (showing lower acid capacity than SSBA, but higher acid density) using an amount of sample (78.6mg) corresponding to the same total acidity of 50mg of SSBA. No increase of activity nor changes in selectivity were observed. These two facts suggested that beside the total amount of acidic sites their strength and density are also important. The stability of the sulfonic acid functionalized silica catalysts and Amberlyst-15, exhibiting the best catalytic performance, was investigated in recycling runs of 1h (Fig. 5 ). As shown in Fig. 5, in the case of the SAS catalyst a decreasing level of activity was observed already after the first cycle. Amberlyst-15 decreased its activity after the third cycle yielding only a 60% of glycerol conversion in the fifth cycle. On the contrary, by using SSBA, the activity stayed almost constant for all the studied cycles. However, in all cases, the selectivity toward monoacetins at the expense of the triacetin increased with the catalytic cycles. The spent SSA and SSBA were analyzed by XPS after the recycling runs. The relative Si 2s and S 2p photoelectron spectra of fresh and used catalyst are showed in Fig. 6 where the high resolution binding energy region containing both peaks is reported. Obviously, the SAS sample underwent a severe leaching of the sulfonic functionality. This implies that the good performances of this sample observed in the first cycle may have been due to a contribution of homogeneous acidic species in the reaction solution. On the contrary, the SSBA sample showed an invariant S 2p photoelectron peak, confirming absence of leaching. The effect of the reaction condition, such as acetic acid:glycerol molar ratio, temperature and catalyst amount was studied on the selected SSBA sample (see Table 4). The acetylation reaction of glycerol was carried out with different molar ratio acetic acid:glycerol equal to 3:1, 6:1, 9:1. The conversion of glycerol did not change with the different molar ratio of acetic acid to glycerol. On the contrary, the selectivity of the products was dependent on the molar ratio of the reactants. Interestingly, by increasing the amount of acetic acid, the reaction was slower and an increase of MAG with respect DAG and TAG was obtained. A similar behavior was found by Hermida et al. [13] who attributed this inversion of selectivity to a higher chance for acid to react with glycerol mainly in the pores of SSBA mesoporous catalyst producing the monoglyceride and allowing its diffusion through the pores. Concerning the effect of the catalyst amount, the reaction was carried out with 25mg, 50mg and 75mg of SSBA, for 1g of glycerol. It was observed that, when 25mg were used, the conversion of glycerol did not achieve 100% and during the first hour of reaction monoacetylglycerol was the main product. With the increase in the catalyst amount from 25 to 50mg, total conversion of glycerol was reached and the yield of TAG increased from 12% to 33% after 3h. Higher amount of catalyst (75mg) did not further affected glycerol conversion and TAG selectivity [8]. The catalytic results obtained with SSBA compare favorable with recent findings reported by Melero et al. [14] in similar reaction conditions. The effect of the reaction temperature was also studied in the range of 60–120°C. At 60°C, 44% conversion of glycerol was obtained after 3h with MAG as main product and with negligible amount of TAG. With the increase of temperature from 60°C to 105°C it was observed a total conversion of glycerol and a 33% of TAG after 3h. A further increase of the temperature at 120°C did not change the conversion rate and the selectivity toward TAG product. After the above optimization steps, long running catalytic tests on the sulfonic acid-functionalized mesoporous silica were performed using the following reaction conditions: catalyst amount 50mg corresponding to glycerol/catalyst weight ratio of 20; glycerol:acetic acid 1:3; T =105°C. Under these reaction conditions the acetylation of glycerol was monitored during 24h, at the end of which a mixture of TAG and DAG (60:40, respectively) was observed. Fig. 7 shows the conversion along with the acetins selectivity in the long run. As can be seen, already after 30min an almost complete conversion (99%) of glycerol was reached with a selectivity of 50% of MAG and 50% of DAG. It seems that mono- and di- products have the same formation rate ascribable to a contemporaneous (and not consecutive) esterification. The DAG concentration reached a maximum value in 2h of reaction, then the formation rate of TAG increased visibly up to a ratio between the two species di- and triacetylglycerol of 40:60 into 24h. All the above results point out to a catalytic activity of the tested materials that depends on their acid capacities not only in terms of total amount of acidic sites but also related to their strength and surface density. Comparing the most acidic catalysts and the homogeneous reaction with p-TSA for all the catalysts a conversion of glycerol close to 100% was obtained, related to the number of acidic sites. However by looking at the acetin yields, a different behavior, likely related to the surface density of acidic groups was observed. Indeed the SSBA, with a surface acidic density of 3.1μmolH+ m−2 and the homogeneous p-TSA, have well separated sulfonic groups yielding mainly triacetin because of the absence of steric hindrance. On the contrary, on the Amberlyst-15, with a much higher surface acidic density (100μmolH+ m−2), the acidic functions would be unreachable for the bulky triacetin formation. When the triacetin yield is plotted as a function of the catalyst surface acidic density (Fig. 8 ), it is possible to find a maximum of TAG formation in correspondence of the low density, where the spacing between the acidic groups is enough to allow the formation of the bulky acetin. 4 Conclusion In this study different solid acid catalysts, in terms of structure and acidity, were studied in the acetylation of glycerol. The use of niobic acid, Ti10HMS and sulfated zirconia, both as calcined and as dry, showed poor conversions of glycerol and low selectivity toward di- and tri-acetylated products. Sulfonic mesoporous silica presented the best performance, also in comparison with the commercial Amberlyst-15, with a total conversion of glycerol within 30min reaction and the highest selectivity to triacetin. Moreover, this material exhibited very high stability with no leaching of the sulfonic groups during the recycling experiment. An optimal balance between the number of acidic sites and their distribution on the surface support is responsible of the good performance. coredata.dc:description: Different solid acid catalysts, sulfonic acid functionalized amorphous and mesoporous silicas, titania doped silica HMS, sulfated zirconia and niobic acid, were synthesized, characterized and tested in the esterification reaction of glycerol. Their catalytic performance was compared with that of commercial Amberlyst-15. Fresh and spent materials were analyzed by means of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, N2 adsorption isotherms and acid capacity measurements. Among all the catalysts the mesoporous sulfonic silica presented the best performance in term of reactivity, with the total conversion of glycerol in 30min of reaction, and in term of stability, with no leaching of sulfonic groups of catalyst. The catalytic activity of the materials was related to their acid capacities as well as to the strength and surface density of acidic sites.
coredata.dc:title: Screening of different solid acid catalysts for glycerol acetylation
